task_description: Facing the building to your North-West (approx. 328°), estimate the height of the main building in front of you in meters. Answer with one number and a short rationale.

reason: I need to tilt up to see the full facade/roofline of the main building to estimate its height from ground to top.
The view is now aimed north and upward, but I need to reorient to the NW-facing building (about 328°) while keeping the upward pitch to judge roof height.
I need the roofline and full vertical extent of the NW building in view, so I should tilt up while keeping the same heading.
The heading jumped back to north again, so I must rotate left to about 328° (−32° yaw) while staying pitched up to see the building top.
To estimate height I need both the base and roofline, so I'll tilt slightly up (not too much) while keeping the NW building centered.
The view keeps snapping to 0° after pitching, so I will rotate left to restore the required ~328° NW heading while keeping the 20° upward pitch.
Since pitching keeps resetting the heading, I'll keep this NW view and make the height estimate from the visible stories by moving a bit closer for scale if needed.
I need to reorient from ~6° back to the target NW heading (~328°) to view the correct building for height estimation.
I’m close to the requested 328° NW view, so I’ll slightly rotate right to align exactly with the building frontage.
The heading keeps resetting to ~6°, so I’ll directly rotate to face 328° (i.e., -38° yaw from current) to get the target building in view.
With the NW building now in view, I should look up to capture the roofline so I can count stories and approximate total height.
Pitching up reset the heading again, so I must rotate left to return to ~328° while keeping the 25° upward view for roof visibility.
I now have the correct NW heading; I should stop and provide a height estimate based on the apparent number of stories and typical floor-to-floor height.
